review_title: There is no way to get more hours.
pros: MATC students are awesome. Faculty are top-notch. Staff is dedicated and hard-working. The college provides outstanding services to the community.
cons: Part-time staff hours are capped at 19, and you will rarely get 19. There's no way you can make a living, even with a high hourly wage, because they keep your hours down. I have tried for years to work toward full-time status, and no positions in my field have been posted.

pros: Great people, lots of interactions.

pros: The school as a whole truly seems to care about serving all kinds of students.

pros: The Institution is great place to work for. Diverse workforce. I enjoy the culture and the team members I work with.

I've never been apart of an organization that is so poor with getting applicants scheduled for interviews. I'm constantly in awe as to how bad this department operates. I often have to apologize to the applicants because of their negative experience.

review_title: Students are great, but management is not

Only employed during fall/spring semesters. Health insurance is expensive through employer. Union does not help out much.

job_title: Commodity Portfolio Manager in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Great company and awesome students

pros: Great staff, wonderful chemistry professors and department, with a beautiful facility, and up-to-date technology.
cons: Highly unorganized administration, possibly due to large campus and COVID difficulties, but accommodates to of student and staff needs.

pros: Health insurance is decent.  Work/life balance is good.
cons: Incompetent leadership and management.  Culture is very negative and anti-employee.  No long term plan for success.  Poor communication and overall work conditions.  Employees are treated terribly by management.  Environment is completely toxic and full of people who are no longer interested in doing their job and should have retired years ago and/or are threatened by new employees.

pros: Depending on the department, management was flexible and very family oriented. He was very encouraging and supportive of continuing higher education. Most faculty really care about the students and their experience at the college. The pay is higher than average.
cons: A lot of staff are rude and are not helpful. Most students' attitudes are terrible (entitlement issues) and rowdy. Staff  give incorrect information to students and most don't care (don't take the time to find the right answer). Staff are catty when it comes to new employees. They don't share knowledge and love it if you fail. They don't like to see anyone do the same job better than them. The reason they have the job is because of tenure and not because of the quality work they should produce. Management does not do a good job in keeping employees who are valuable (come to work on time, perform their duties, professional, perform above and beyond, smart, etc); rather they cater to trouble employees who are unprofessional. Management is very passive but yet they complain about the same employees. MATC administrators do not care how much money students pay to get into college or the admissions process. Administrators like to portray that MATC cares about the community but they only care about how much money they make (always six figures plus other benefits). Administrators are aware of staff and other highly paid administrators who steal time (say they are at work when they are actually completing papers to earn their Ph.D. or Masters, or using MATC hours to work at their other jobs). MATC wastes a lot of time with archaic procedures. Most Administrators and management use good employees to make processes better and take credit. Broken procedures are not update but rather worked around affecting students negatively. MATC has forgotten that the school exists because students are there (students are not valued and good employees are not acknowledged).

pros: There are some really good people who work here who enjoy helping students
cons: Communication between departments is horrible. There are a lot of lazy employees that don't care and don't work for the good pay they receive. Bad managers get shuffled off to other departments instead of being let go.

review_title: An archetype and idealization of joint governance - this school is successfully run by both the union and administration
job_title: Social Science Instructor in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Fair pay, none of the usual exploitation of college professor professionalism, good benefits, interesting student body, joint governance (school is run by core committees that have balanced representation from the teacher's union and administration, current administration is very pro-education, pro-teacher, pro-student). Very strong shared sense of the education mission, this is a great place to work for education professionals who want to make a difference and make a decent living at the same time.  I was a wandering adjunct in the Chicago area for years, so I can make a very valid comparison, this is by far the best higher education place of work I've found in the tri-state area.  The cons are unusual and unique, but keep in perspective, overall, this two year college is the best place to work for an academic who wants to teach (it's not a place for those oriented towards research, it's a two year technical college).
cons: Aging faculty can be a problem at times.  Although in general, those with more teaching time have more experience, and thus, are usually more effective teachers and helpful colleagues, this faculty is very lopsided on the side of those on the verge of retirement (too many should have retired years ago).  They can be a powerful passive force resisting progress.  For example, we have this antiquated method of choosing textbooks (the whole department votes, or a committee decides the textbook for all sections of each course) dating back long before the Internet, and possibly before color televisions.  The over 60 voting block NEVER votes to change the existing textbook (too much work to change the syllabus perfected back when Nixon was President), so it takes a very unlikely set of circumstances to bring about a textbook change.  Support staff are often very good, but many, especially in key positions, don't like either students or professors, but are unofficially granted great powers of discretion.  For example, the mail room people don't like professors who get a lot of books delivered to them, and will punish those of us who do by intentionally misdirecting our mail.  Some student advisors have no idea what college is about, and give students just terrible advice (i.e. "take all online classes, they are always easier."), that is sometimes difficult to undo.  You don't get the nice office that is common to most other colleges, you get a corporate style cubby, and our homepage and other computer related issues are spectacularly inadequate.  You can't search for department information or instructor contact information from our home page!  Instructors have no access to statistical software!  After 5 years, I'm still often amazed at how our problems are so unlike other colleges.

pros: I have worked as both faculty and staff. The staff and faculty are very competent and thorough, they put students first and are sincerely concerned about their welfare. I feel happy to be a part of this.
cons: The communication between admin and staff and faculty isn't what it should be. I also have found almost all staff personnel to be friendly and helpful while some of the faculty are standoffish and not to be bothered.

review_title: It was a nice place to work at with good people that show me a lot in my 11yrs,there.

cons: Sometimes it was the people they had as leaders was not good they didn't know what they was doing at times .
